title: Sexuality, birth control, love and marriage in England 1918-1960: an oral history study
abstractText: This research will produce a co-authored book of social history, which will present for the first time an historical interpretation of sexual attitudes and practices in marriage, along with their birth controlling preferences, drawn from the direct testimony of the oldest generation of the twentieth century, those born between 1900 and 1930. The book presents first hand evidence systematically collected from in depth oral history interviews with approximately 90 married men and women from contrasting social groups drawn from both the middle and the working classes living in very different communities in the north and the south of England.
